neighbors.name: Bron & Shellie Howard
neighbors.claims: The Howard family is an established farming presence in Headrick, raising wheat and cattle on a 2,500-acre Jackson County farm that has been in the family since 1884 [Oklahoma Farm Bureau](https://okfbfoundationforagriculture.org/producer-perspective/bob-and-renee-howard-headrick-ok/). Like many local producers, the Howards tend to focus on agriculture and avoid public complaints or political activism [Oklahoma Farm Bureau](https://okfbfoundationforagriculture.org/producer-perspective/bob-and-renee-howard-headrick-ok/).

approach_recommendations.engage: Have a respected local farmer or Farm Bureau member approach them, emphasizing respect for their family’s land legacy and minimal disruption to their farming routine.

neighbors.name: Shane & Lori Reaser
neighbors.claims: Lori Reaser (née Reaser) was raised in the Altus area; she is identified as the daughter of longtime Altus residents Joe Don and Sherrie Reaser ([www.harmoncountyfuneral.com](https://www.harmoncountyfuneral.com/obituaries/Kevin-Dean-Reaser?obId=2896237#:~:text=Kevin%20Dean%20Reaser%20was%20born,Phil%20and%20Joy%20Phillips%20of)). The Reaser family holds multiple parcels of agricultural land in Jackson County, suggesting a significant farming operation similar to other large farm families in the region [Oklahoma Farm Bureau](https://okfbfoundationforagriculture.org/producer-perspective/bob-and-renee-howard-headrick-ok/).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage via a fellow farmer or agricultural extension contact who knows them. Stress how project plans will protect farmland integrity and maintain property values.

neighbors.name: Troy D. Metheny III
neighbors.claims: Troy D. Metheny III’s public records show previous addresses in Hollis, Oklahoma (Harmon County) and even out-of-state, indicating he may not reside full-time in Jackson County ([veripages.com](https://veripages.com/name/Troy/Metheny/#:~:text=Veripages%20veripages,Hollis%2C%20OK%2073550%20See%20Troy%27s)). He carries a generational suffix (“III”), but no local news or civic documents mention him, suggesting he maintains a very low public profile in the community ([veripages.com](https://veripages.com/name/Troy/Metheny/#:~:text=Veripages%20veripages,Hollis%2C%20OK%2073550%20See%20Troy%27s)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Because he appears to live off-site, reach out via certified mail or a phone call to discuss the project and address any property-specific concerns directly.

neighbors.name: Stuart & Karen Ferguson
neighbors.claims: Karen R. Ferguson, 73, was a Headrick resident who passed away in December 2020 ([www.harmoncountyfuneral.com](https://www.harmoncountyfuneral.com/obituaries/Karen-Ferguson?obId=19264077#:~:text=Obituary%20for%20Karen%20Ferguson)); she is survived by her husband Stuart Ferguson at their home in Headrick ([www.harmoncountyfuneral.com](https://www.harmoncountyfuneral.com/obituaries/Karen-Ferguson?obId=19264077#:~:text=Karen%20is%20survived%20her%20husband,wife%20Lyne%20Whorton%20of%20Tulsa)). Stuart Ferguson served at Altus Air Force Base during his military career and, after a period of working as house parents at a Baptist children’s home, the couple settled into retirement life in rural Jackson County ([www.harmoncountyfuneral.com](https://www.harmoncountyfuneral.com/obituaries/Karen-Ferguson?obId=19264077#:~:text=Oklahoma,Homes%20for%20Children%20for%20five)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Have a fellow veteran or community member known to them start a conversation. Emphasize how the project will respect their peaceful retirement and not intrude on their quiet lifestyle.

neighbors.name: Michael & Linda Dishman
neighbors.claims: No notable public information was found on Michael or Linda Dishman; their names do not surface in available local news, suggesting they have not taken on visible community roles ([gateway.okhistory.org](https://gateway.okhistory.org/ark%3A/67531/metadc2187242/m1/9/#:~:text=The%20Altus%20Times%20%28Altus%2C%20Okla,JK%20JONES%20HOWARD%20D%20FRANCIS)). Like many long-term rural landowners, they appear to keep a low profile, focusing on their property and daily life rather than public issues ([okfbfoundationforagriculture.org](https://okfbfoundationforagriculture.org/producer-perspective/bob-and-renee-howard-headrick-ok/#:~:text=Like%20many%20of%20Oklahoma%E2%80%99s%20farmers,you%20won%E2%80%99t%20hear%20him%20complain)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach casually through a neighborly visit or local acquaintance. Reassure them that the project will be unobtrusive and respect the calm and privacy of the area.

neighbors.name: Kenneth Helton & Neoma Linares
neighbors.claims: Kenneth Helton and Neoma Linares are brother and sister from a longtime Jackson County family; Neoma was born in Altus in 1945 ([www.melanconlevingston.com](https://www.melanconlevingston.com/obituaries/neoma-linares#:~:text=Neoma%20Lee%20Linares%2C%20a%20beloved,in%20family%20values%20and%20faith)) ([www.melanconlevingston.com](https://www.melanconlevingston.com/obituaries/neoma-linares#:~:text=sisters%2C%20Nelda%20Linares%20and%20her,Helton%20and%20his%20wife%2C%20Jo)). Neoma Linares passed away on October 19, 2025, at age 80 ([www.melanconlevingston.com](https://www.melanconlevingston.com/obituaries/neoma-linares#:~:text=July%201%2C%201945%20%E2%80%94%20October,19%2C%202025)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Have a respected local farmer or family friend introduce the project, emphasizing respect for the Helton family’s land legacy and minimal impact on their farmland.

neighbors.name: Annette & George Benbow
neighbors.claims: Annette and George Benbow jointly own property in Jackson County (each noted with a one-half interest) ([www.datacrosspoint.com](https://www.datacrosspoint.com/jackson-county-property-search/#:~:text=1,mortgage%20histories%2C%20market%20trends%2C%20and)), but neither appears in any public records of civic engagement or local governance (their name yields no entries in county filings) ([okcountyrecords.com](https://okcountyrecords.com/search/jackson#:~:text=No%20,benbow)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Use a neighborly, informal approach (perhaps through a mutual acquaintance) to open dialogue. Emphasize local oversight and listen to any concerns to reassure them that community interests will be respected.

neighbors.name: Betty L. Walls
neighbors.claims: Betty L. Walls is listed as the owner of two adjacent parcels in the Headrick area (implying a residence and surrounding land) ([www.datacrosspoint.com](https://www.datacrosspoint.com/jackson-county-property-search/#:~:text=1,mortgage%20histories%2C%20market%20trends%2C%20and)). There is no record of Betty Walls taking part in local meetings or making public statements on development (her name does not surface in accessible county or news archives) ([okcountyrecords.com](https://okcountyrecords.com/search/jackson#:~:text=No%20,walls)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage her in a personal conversation through someone she trusts in the community, highlighting that the project will maintain the quiet rural character and protect property values in the area.

neighbors.name: Gregory K. & Julie M. Carpenter
neighbors.claims: Gregory K. Carpenter and Julie M. Carpenter are co-owners of a parcel near Headrick ([www.datacrosspoint.com](https://www.datacrosspoint.com/jackson-county-property-search/#:~:text=1,mortgage%20histories%2C%20market%20trends%2C%20and)). They have no known public profile in Jackson County affairs and have not been identified in any local development disputes or civic roles ([okcountyrecords.com](https://okcountyrecords.com/search/jackson#:~:text=No%20,carpenter)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Meet with the Carpenter family together and offer clear information. Emphasize transparent, fair terms and how the project will address any practical concerns, to earn their trust through honest communication.

neighbors.name: Justin Tanner Carpenter
neighbors.claims: Justin Tanner Carpenter owns a separate parcel in the same vicinity ([www.datacrosspoint.com](https://www.datacrosspoint.com/jackson-county-property-search/#:~:text=1,mortgage%20histories%2C%20market%20trends%2C%20and)). Like the other Carpenters, he has no documented involvement in community meetings or stated opinions on development projects (no entries under his name in public records) ([okcountyrecords.com](https://okcountyrecords.com/search/jackson#:~:text=No%20,carpenter)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach Justin Carpenter with a peer-to-peer conversation (possibly via a mutual friend or neighbor) and highlight the safety measures and community benefits of the project. Ensuring he feels heard and that agreements are straightforward will help gain his confidence.

neighbors.name: Glyna Gaye Olson & John Phillip Olson
neighbors.claims: John Phillip Olson, listing an address in Olustee (Jackson County), received over $2,500 in federal farm assistance through the USDA’s Emergency Conservation Program ([farm.ewg.org](https://farm.ewg.org/top_recips.php?fips=40065&page=1&progcode=em_cons#:~:text=21%20%20,%242%2C333)). No public statements or civic roles involving the Olsons were found in local news or county records as of 2025 .

approach_recommendations.engage: Have a fellow local farmer or extension agent reach out, emphasizing how the project can coexist with farming interests.

neighbors.name: Carl Todd Bridges
neighbors.claims: Carl “Todd” Bridges owns multiple parcels in Jackson County near Headrick (per county property records) ([webserver2.okcountyrecords.com](https://webserver2.okcountyrecords.com/search/jackson?query=omni%3DS25%2BT01S%2BR24W%3Asite%3Djackson#:~:text=Jackson%20County%20County%20Clerk%20,images%20from%20October%2C%202003%20New)). There is no indication in available public sources that Bridges has taken a public position on local development proposals or held any prominent community office .

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage via a casual introduction from a mutual acquaintance in the area, listening for any concerns about property impacts and offering information one-on-one.

neighbors.name: Travis G. Walls & Betty L. Walls
neighbors.claims: Travis G. Walls and Betty L. Walls are listed together as landowners on a rural Jackson County parcel ([webserver2.okcountyrecords.com](https://webserver2.okcountyrecords.com/search/jackson?query=omni%3DS25%2BT01S%2BR24W%3Asite%3Djackson#:~:text=Jackson%20County%20,images%20from%20October%2C%202003%20New)). No record of the Walls family participating in zoning meetings or voicing opinions on energy projects was identified in local records .

approach_recommendations.engage: Reach out through a friendly local community member who knows them, and reassure them that their privacy and daily routine will be respected by the project.

neighbors.name: Public Service Company of Oklahoma
neighbors.claims: See ORG table.

approach_recommendations.engage: Coordinate through formal channels; PSO will evaluate the project’s grid interconnection and regulatory compliance.

neighbors.name: Donnie Lee Shiplet & Elicia Dawn Shiplet
neighbors.claims: Donnie Shiplet is from a local family; he was noted as a surviving son of longtime Altus resident Kenny Mac Shiplet ([www.lowell-tims.com](https://www.lowell-tims.com/obituaries/Kenny-Mac-Shiplet?obId=2896262#:~:text=children%2C%20Lorie%20Collier%20of%20Yukon%2C,children%2C%20Patricia%20Shannan)). The Shiplets have no documented history of public comments on development or involvement in local governance bodies .

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage the couple through a neighborly conversation via a mutual friend, highlighting any benefits to the local community and addressing their questions in an informal setting.

neighbors.name: Trina Adams
neighbors.claims: Trina Adams is from a long-time Headrick farming family; her late father Richard W. Adams grew up farming on the river bend there ([www.lowell-tims.com](https://www.lowell-tims.com/obituaries/Richard-Wayne-Adams?obId=2904100#:~:text=farm%20on%20the%20river%20bend,Barbara%20Dailey%20at%20the%20Baptist)) and even worked as a night watchman at the local cotton gin co-op for many years ([www.lowell-tims.com](https://www.lowell-tims.com/obituaries/Richard-Wayne-Adams?obId=2904100#:~:text=Church%20in%20Headrick,doing%20his%20own%20work%20at)). She has no recorded public statements or roles on local development issues ([www.kswo.com](https://www.kswo.com/story/21101399/southwest-oklahoma-municipal-election-slates-set/#:~:text=Headrick)).
neighbors.influence_justification: Old local farm family, no public office

approach_recommendations.engage: Reach out via trusted farming community contacts who knew her family, emphasizing respect for her family’s land legacy and how the project can align with preserving that heritage.

neighbors.name: Norma Wright
neighbors.claims: Norma Wright is listed as a landowner in the Headrick area but maintains an extremely low public profile ([www.kswo.com](https://www.kswo.com/story/21101399/southwest-oklahoma-municipal-election-slates-set/#:~:text=Headrick)). There are no mentions of her in local news or civic records, indicating she has not publicly voiced opinions on development projects ([www.kswo.com](https://www.kswo.com/story/21101399/southwest-oklahoma-municipal-election-slates-set/#:~:text=Headrick)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage the Wrights in person through a neighbor or local farm bureau acquaintance they trust. Emphasize one-on-one conversation focusing on listening to any concerns about their land use and assuring minimal disruption.

neighbors.name: Cornelio Rangel
neighbors.claims: Cornelio Rangel owns property near Headrick but has no evident public presence or community roles ([www.kswo.com](https://www.kswo.com/story/21101399/southwest-oklahoma-municipal-election-slates-set/#:~:text=Headrick)). No public records or media coverage were found linking him to any stance on development or local civic activities ([www.kswo.com](https://www.kswo.com/story/21101399/southwest-oklahoma-municipal-election-slates-set/#:~:text=Headrick)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach Mr. Rangel through a personal, relationship-building visit (potentially with a bilingual community liaison if appropriate). Ensure he understands the project plans in plain terms and that his property and routine will be respected.

neighbors.name: William Wright
neighbors.claims: William Wright is a significant landowner holding multiple parcels in the Headrick vicinity (indicating a sizeable farming operation) ([www.kswo.com](https://www.kswo.com/story/21101399/southwest-oklahoma-municipal-election-slates-set/#:~:text=Headrick)). He has not taken on any visible public roles; his name does not appear in reports of local elections or meetings, and he has made no known public statements on development proposals ([www.kswo.com](https://www.kswo.com/story/21101399/southwest-oklahoma-municipal-election-slates-set/#:~:text=Headrick)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Have a respected fellow farmer or agricultural extension agent initiate contact with William. In discussions, stress how the project will protect his farmland’s productivity and address any concerns about land or infrastructure (like field access or road wear).

neighbors.name: Kevin and Manette Lewis
neighbors.claims: Kevin and Manette Lewis jointly own a parcel near Headrick ([www.kswo.com](https://www.kswo.com/story/21101399/southwest-oklahoma-municipal-election-slates-set/#:~:text=Headrick)). They have no public profile in the community; no news articles or local records mention them taking any position on development or participating in local civic matters ([www.kswo.com](https://www.kswo.com/story/21101399/southwest-oklahoma-municipal-election-slates-set/#:~:text=Headrick)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Connect with the Lewis family through a casual, neighborly conversation. Emphasize that community input is valued and explain how the project will be managed to avoid harming property values or the quiet rural atmosphere they enjoy.

neighbors.name: Anita Miller
neighbors.claims: Anita Miller lives in Altus but comes from a family that has farmed near Headrick since the early 1950s ([www.lowell-tims.com](https://www.lowell-tims.com/obituaries/Doris-June-Miller?obId=44881859#:~:text=sisters%2C,1992%20after%20a%20dedicated%20career)) ([www.lowell-tims.com](https://www.lowell-tims.com/obituaries/Doris-June-Miller?obId=44881859#:~:text=preceded%20in%20death%20by%20her,Jerry%29%20Whitten%20of)). She is a daughter of the late Carroll and Doris Miller, who established a farm homestead near Headrick in 1952 ([www.lowell-tims.com](https://www.lowell-tims.com/obituaries/Doris-June-Miller?obId=44881859#:~:text=sisters%2C,1992%20after%20a%20dedicated%20career)) ([www.lowell-tims.com](https://www.lowell-tims.com/obituaries/Doris-June-Miller?obId=44881859#:~:text=preceded%20in%20death%20by%20her,Jerry%29%20Whitten%20of)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Use a personal, respectful approach highlighting understanding of her family’s long local history and listening to any concerns.

neighbors.name: Howco, Inc.
neighbors.claims: Howco, Inc. appears to be associated with the Howard family farm in Headrick, which spans approximately 2,500 acres of wheat and cattle operations ([okfbfoundationforagriculture.org](https://okfbfoundationforagriculture.org/producer-perspective/bob-and-renee-howard-headrick-ok/#:~:text=Farming%20and%20ranching%20is%20a,prior%20to%20statehood%20in%201884)). The Howard family has been farming in Jackson County for generations (homesteading since 1884), indicating a long-standing local presence ([okfbfoundationforagriculture.org](https://okfbfoundationforagriculture.org/producer-perspective/bob-and-renee-howard-headrick-ok/#:~:text=Farming%20and%20ranching%20is%20a,prior%20to%20statehood%20in%201884)). No separate corporate website or public profile exists for Howco, Inc., suggesting it functions as a private holding entity for the Howard farming enterprise. The Howard farm (likely under Howco) is a prominent local agricultural producer, with Bob Howard continuing the family legacy and active in the farming community ([okfbfoundationforagriculture.org](https://okfbfoundationforagriculture.org/producer-perspective/bob-and-renee-howard-headrick-ok/#:~:text=Farming%20and%20ranching%20is%20a,prior%20to%20statehood%20in%201884)).
neighbors.influence_justification: Multi-generational local farm (Howard family) controlling ~2,500 acres; longstanding involvement in local agriculture networks

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage family patriarch Bob Howard through the Farm Bureau or local ag leaders; emphasize minimal impact on farming and potential benefits to cattle or land value; anticipate scrutiny of land use changes due to their deep ties

neighbors.name: Flying B Land & Cattle Co. LLC
neighbors.claims: Flying B Land & Cattle Co. LLC is registered in Oklahoma (formed Jan 18, 2008) with Terry J. Barker as its agent, using a Tulsa address ([businessprofiles.com](https://businessprofiles.com/details/flying-b-grain-cattle-co-llc/OK-3512167393#:~:text=,Agent)). The company’s name suggests ranching interests (“Land & Cattle”), but there is no public-facing presence or local operations information. Its formation by an out-of-area principal indicates it may function as an investment vehicle holding Jackson County land rather than an active local ranch. No media or community activities are associated with Flying B, implying a low-profile, absentee ownership focused on the land asset itself.
neighbors.influence_justification: Absentee ownership (Tulsa-based principal); no known local role beyond owning land

approach_recommendations.engage: Contact Terry Barker (registered agent) or authorized representative with a clear financial proposal; highlight buyout or lease terms that monetize the land, as absentee owners are likely driven by ROI over local concerns

neighbors.name: The Pamela A. Roudebush Living Trust
neighbors.claims: The Pamela A. Roudebush Living Trust holds farmland tied to the Roudebush family, a prominent long-time farming family in Jackson County ([www.legacy.com](https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/legacyremembers/robert-roudebush-obituary?id=14252530#:~:text=On%20June%2019%2C%201964%2C%20Roudy,muscle%20cars%2C%20drag%20racing%2C%20snow)). The late Robert “Roudy” Roudebush farmed and ranched in the area for 50 years and served on boards of the local farmers’ cooperative, cotton gin, and the Lugert-Altus Irrigation District ([www.legacy.com](https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/legacyremembers/robert-roudebush-obituary?id=14252530#:~:text=fifty%20years%2C%20Roudy%20has%20farmed%2C,muscle%20cars%2C%20drag%20racing%2C%20snow)), reflecting substantial community standing. The trust presumably was established for estate planning after Robert’s passing in 2014, with Pamela (his widow) and possibly their children as beneficiaries. Given this legacy, the Roudebush Trust’s land is managed to continue family farming operations, and the trustees are likely sensitive to any development that could disrupt agriculture or diminish the land’s value.
neighbors.influence_justification: Legacy family farm with leadership roles in local ag institutions; respected, long-term community members

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach the Roudebush family trustees with respect for their heritage; propose assurances (e.g., buffer zones, continued irrigation access) to address farming concerns; be prepared for strong defense of farmland use

neighbors.name: AFL Farms, LLC
neighbors.claims: AFL Farms, LLC is a small Altus-based farming operation led by President Austin Leverette ([farmlovers.org](https://farmlovers.org/community/altus/farms/921#:~:text=,9932%20Full%20Profile)). The LLC has been part of the local farming community for around nine years and recently expanded into niche agriculture (referred to as an “almond culture” venture) ([farmlovers.org](https://farmlovers.org/community/altus/farms/921#:~:text=,9932%20Full%20Profile)). AFL Farms markets locally, participating in an Altus fresh produce marketplace to reach regional customers ([farmlovers.org](https://farmlovers.org/community/altus/farms/921#:~:text=,9932%20Full%20Profile)). The business appears to be an independent family farm startup, without large-scale acreage, focusing on specialty crops and direct community engagement.
neighbors.influence_justification: Newer small-scale farm; limited land holdings and modest presence (direct-to-market niche)

approach_recommendations.engage: Reach out personally to Austin Leverette to understand any concerns (e.g., impact on his orchard/produce operations); explore goodwill gestures (community garden space, sponsorship) to secure goodwill given his direct-to-community focus

neighbors.name: JEH, LLC
neighbors.claims: JEH, LLC is an opaque entity with no public profile or known business operations. Its presence is only noted in county property ownership records (as the listed owner of parcel 330002641), and no information about its members or activities is readily available. No corporate website, news mentions, or state filings (beyond basic registration) could be found for JEH, LLC, suggesting it functions purely as a private land-holding company. The beneficial owner and specific motivations of JEH, LLC remain unidentified in public sources.
neighbors.influence_justification: Ownership structure and principals not publicly known; no evident community engagement or local identity

approach_recommendations.engage: Identify the owner or agent through county records and approach with a straightforward proposition (they have no public stance to gauge); be prepared for low engagement if it’s a passive investor, or to address any concerns if a private individual surfaces as the owner

neighbors.name: Jackson County Water Company
neighbors.claims: Jackson County Water Company is a nonprofit rural water utility (501(c)(12)) that has operated in the area since 1973 [ProPublica](https://projects.propublica.org/nonprofits/organizations/730929547). The co-op reported about $1.3 million in revenue and $3.98 million in total assets in 2023, reflecting its substantial service role in the community [ProPublica](https://projects.propublica.org/nonprofits/organizations/730929547). Volunteer directors (e.g., Justin Abernathy as Vice President) manage the utility, indicating local community control [ProPublica](https://projects.propublica.org/nonprofits/organizations/730929547). Its mission statement prioritizes providing high-quality water service and environmental conservation for the community [Jackson County Water Company](https://jacksoncountywater.net/).
neighbors.influence_justification: Essential rural utility serving a broad customer base; long-standing local institution with stable finances and community trust

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage the cooperative’s board leadership early to address any water or environmental concerns; emphasize that the project will not harm water resources, aligning with their conservation mission

neighbors.name: Prairie Properties, LLC
neighbors.claims: Prairie Properties LLC is a privately-owned real estate management firm based in Oklahoma City, focusing on residential and commercial property management [MapQuest](https://www.mapquest.com/us/oklahoma/prairie-properties-llc-420582743). The company operates on a small scale (estimated under $500,000 annual revenue, 5-10 employees) and is not publicly traded or widely known [Cortera](https://start.cortera.com/company/research/k3q9mzr5p/prairie-properties-llc/). It holds at least one rural parcel in Jackson County, suggesting an interest in land investment or speculation outside its primary urban market [Jackson County Clerk](https://okcountyrecords.com/search/jackson). Beneficial ownership is not publicly disclosed, and no local affiliations are evident in public records [Jackson County Clerk](https://okcountyrecords.com/search/jackson).
neighbors.influence_justification: Out-of-area land investor with no local presence or political ties; limited economic impact locally

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach the LLC’s owner or manager with a clearly profitable offer (purchase or lease) to encourage cooperation, as their interest is likely purely financial

neighbors.name: Frank, Donald P. Living Trust
neighbors.claims: The Donald P. Frank Living Trust is a private family trust holding this land for an individual landowner, rather than an active business organization (see RESIDENT table for details) [Jackson County Clerk](https://okcountyrecords.com/search/jackson). No corporate filings or business activities are associated with this trust, as it represents personal ownership of the property.
neighbors.influence_justification: Private landowner with no organizational structure; influence limited to personal reputation and relationships in the community

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage the landowner (or family) respectfully and in person, addressing any personal or legacy concerns; emphasize careful land stewardship and ensure any offer reflects fair value to the family

neighbors.name: DLW Development, LLC
neighbors.claims: DLW Development, LLC is an Oklahoma limited liability company that owns a parcel in Jackson County; it has no discernible public presence or known projects beyond this land holding [Jackson County Clerk](https://okcountyrecords.com/search/jackson). No media mentions or detailed filings could be found for this entity, indicating it may be a small private landholder or a speculative vehicle with inactive operations [Jackson County Clerk](https://okcountyrecords.com/search/jackson).
neighbors.influence_justification: Little-known LLC with no public profile or community role; likely no local influence beyond property ownership

approach_recommendations.engage: Research the principals behind this LLC to gauge their intentions; if they are purely speculating on land value, offer a favorable buyout or partnership to secure their support or acquiescence

overview_summary: All five neighboring landowners have an undetermined stance on development, with no explicit support or opposition documented. Most exert limited community influence; none hold public office, though a couple of families (like the Howards and Reasers) command respect as established farm owners. None of these five neighboring landowners has a documented public stance on the proposed development, so their positions remain unknown. All are private individuals (no corporate owners), and none holds an official role or local leadership position, indicating generally low community influence across the group. None of the adjacent landowners have made a clear public stance for or against development, with all profiles showing an unknown position on the project. Most appear to be ordinary residents without notable public roles, suggesting a generally low level of community influence among these neighbors. None of these neighbors have made any public stance on the development known. All five are local landowners with limited public profiles or civic roles. Only one (a multi-parcel farm owner) might exert moderate community influence, while the rest appear to have low influence. One neighboring landowner has an undocumented stance on development and appears to wield limited community influence. This neighbor comes from a long-established local farm family but holds no known public office or leadership role. The neighboring entities around the Headrick site are predominantly family-run agricultural operations (multi-generational farms and ranches) with one out-of-town investment LLC. The smaller or non-local owners (AFL Farms LLC, Flying B Land & Cattle, JEH LLC) have more limited community influence and may be driven more by financial considerations than local advocacy.
